ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A brief overview of Russias relationship with the East.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength  Paul Bushkovitchs deep knowledge 

Weakness  Disorganized nature of the course, lack of feedback

Strengths: Really interesting material, very knowledgeable professor
Weaknesses: Some readings went very deep on topics that were unfamiliar to most students, so there's definitely a bit of a learning curve at the start of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not really. Prof Bushkovitch is obviously very knowledgeable in his field, but he doesnt provide useful feedback and the class is very lecture heavy. Prof Bushkovitchs sense of humor makes it easier to bear, but its still rather boring.
Yes, it's a fascinating course taught by one of the most experienced professors at Yale! Only issues were the small class size and that sometimes the reading were really long.

Absolutely! I would definitely recommend "Russia and the Eurasian Steppe." Though I already entered the course with personal interest regarding the topic, as well as some basic background historical knowledge, I think anybody could really enjoy and learn a lot from this course. This is especially the case if Professor Bushkovitch is teaching the course! He is an incredible instructor, and clearly an expert who is passionate about the class topics. His humor is an additional plus. The content is so fascinating, and the readings are very interesting (especially the primary sources).

extras.title: HIST 222J 01/RSEE 222 01 - Russia and the Eurasian Steppe
